title: Sudbrook (stream)
text:
Sudbrook and its tributary, the Latchmere stream, are north-flowing <a href="stream">stream</a>s in London, England, that drain northern <a href="Kingston%20upon%20Thames">Kingston upon Thames</a> and the eastern extreme of <a href="Ham%2C%20London">Ham</a> following a <a href="meander%20scar">meander scar</a> in a <a href="Fluvial%20terrace">terrace</a>; the upper part of the Sudbrook drains a narrow vale in <a href="Richmond%20Park">Richmond Park</a>'s southern corner into the <a href="Tideway">tidal Thames</a>.
Sudbrook.
Sudbrook (from 'South brook') rises at the small pond south of "Dann's Pond", at about elevation, in the far south of <a href="Richmond%20Park">Richmond Park</a>, flowing <a href="boxing%20the%20compass">NNW</a> to Ham Gate. It forms a small valley, Ham Dip, and has been dammed and enlarged in two places to form 'Ham Dip Pond' and 'Ham Gate Pond', first mapped in 1861 and 1754 respectively. These were created for the watering of deer. Both saw restoration including de-silting, completed in 2013. It drains the western <a href="escarpment">escarpment</a> of the hill that, to the east, forms part of the catchment of <a href="Beverley%20Brook">Beverley Brook</a> and, to the south, the <a href="Hogsmill%20River">Hogsmill River</a>.
Sudbrook is joined by the Latchmere stream just beyond Ham Gate Pond. It then flows into <a href="Sudbrook%20Park%2C%20Petersham">Sudbrook Park, Petersham</a>, and is <a href="culvert">culvert</a>ed for the remainder of its course, discharging into the tidal River Thames to the east of 'River Lane' where the culvert outfall is protected from tidal <a href="Backflow%20%28plumbing%29">backflow</a> by a flap valve.
Before culverting, the stream used to flow alongside the <a href="A307%20road">A307 road</a> in Petersham and was crossed by a <a href="ford%20%28crossing%29">ford</a> at Sudbrook Lane. The collapse of this culvert in the late 1970s, referred to as the <a href="Petersham%20Hole">Petersham Hole</a>, caused widespread traffic disruption for over a year.
Latchmere stream.
Latchmere probably combines <a href="Old%20French">Old French</a> '<a href="laches%20%28equity%29">lache</a>', lazy or slow-moving and <a href="Old%20English">Old English</a> '<a href="mere%20%28lake%29">mere</a>', a lake or pond; it may however relate to <a href="lammas%20land">lammas land</a>, a type of common land with church associations.
The "Latchmere stream" or "Latchmere brook" started as drainage <a href="ditch">ditch</a>es in the <a href="Canbury">Canbury</a> manor to the north-east of <a href="Kingston%20railway%20station%20%28London%29">Kingston railway station</a> that, historically in low gradient seasonally flooded. Flooding is abated by some drains in its catchment now draining to the Thames or Hogsmill River and by many soakaways for the roof of homes. Some surface water still drains north-east then north, added to by percolation of water in Richmond Park into the very small, hillside Gallows Pond. Exactly 305 metres of the south of the Kings Road forms its abrupt dip in Richmond Park's south-west side. Owing to flood deposition centuries ago of the untamed river Thames, the Thames/Latchmere watershed (divide), from the town northward shifts eastward e.g. is 220m from Richmond Road, as to Latchmere Road.
The stream's lower course lines the south of the east side of <a href="Ham%20Common%2C%20London">Ham Common</a>, about 50 metres west of Ham Gate of the Richmond Park, via which it joins the Sudbrook just below Ham Gate Pond which together skirt the west side of the Park against the Common.
From <a href="Roman%20Britain">Roman</a> to <a href="Saxon%20England">Saxon England</a> or later, the north of Kingston town centre formed a series of island fields formed by a branch of the Hogsmill River and a drainage channel linked to this stream.
With the increase of urbanisation of Kingston in the early 19th century, residents of Canbury used many of their ditches as open sewers, causing a public nuisance and a health hazard: "The stench from this ditch, which is an open one, is always bad, but in summer it is beyond words to describe" reported the Kingston <a href="Board%20of%20Guardians">Board of Guardians</a> on 19 June 1866. This and other open sewers were the cause of serious public health problems, and by in the early 1890s a sewerage works served Kingston, on the Thames. However the slow brook, used as or percolating to the main source of water for a few, still caused some fatal <a href="Diarrhea">infant diarrhoea</a> and <a href="diphtheria">diphtheria</a>. Public information not to drink from streams, ditches or shallow wells in urban zones was widespread by the early 20th century.
Expansion of residential housing across former agricultural land has resulted in the Latchmere stream being culverted, but its course is revealed during periods of heavy rainfall. Its streets are the subject of <a href="pluvial">pluvial</a> flood risk management.
